name: ACQUIRED
description: One entity purchasing another entity, typically involving the transfer of ownership and control. This includes mergers, acquisitions, and buying majority stakes.
examples: Alphabet Inc. completed the purchase of the fitness tracker company Fitbit for $2.1 billion.
Salesforce signed a definitive agreement to buy Slack Technologies.

name: SUED
description: One entity initiating legal proceedings against another entity. This includes filing lawsuits, patent disputes, and other legal complaints.
examples: Waymo filed a legal complaint against Uber alleging theft of trade secrets.
Epic Games took Apple to court over App Store fees and policies.

name: PARTNERED
description: Two or more entities agreeing to cooperate to advance their mutual interests. This includes strategic alliances, joint ventures, and collaboration agreements.
examples: Microsoft and OpenAI announced a multi-year agreement to accelerate AI breakthroughs.
Starbucks and Spotify joined forces to create a music ecosystem for coffee shops.

name: INVESTED
description: One entity allocating capital to another entity with the expectation of a future financial return. This includes venture capital funding, equity stakes, and buying shares.
examples: Berkshire Hathaway bought a significant stake in Snowflake prior to its IPO.
Andreessen Horowitz led the Series A funding round for the new crypto startup.

name: DIVESTED
description: One entity disposing of a business unit, subsidiary, or investment. This includes spin-offs, selling off assets, or reducing ownership stakes.
examples: eBay spun off PayPal into a separate publicly traded company.
General Electric sold its biopharma business to Danaher Corporation.

name: HIRED
description: An entity employing a person, often an executive or key figure, from another entity or generally.
examples: Uber appointed the former Expedia CEO as its new Chief Executive Officer.
Tesla recruited a top battery researcher from Dalhousie University.

name: REGULATED
description: A government or regulatory body imposing rules, fines, or restrictions on an entity. This includes antitrust actions, investigations, and compliance orders.
examples: The European Commission fined Google for antitrust violations related to Android.
The SEC charged the crypto exchange with operating an unregistered securities offering.

name: LAUNCHED_PRODUCT
description: An entity introducing a new product or service to the market.
examples: Apple unveiled the Vision Pro headset at its annual developer conference.
Amazon rolled out a new pharmacy service for Prime members.

name: EXPANDED
description: An entity increasing its operations, physical footprint, or market presence. This includes opening new offices, entering new countries, or increasing production capacity.
examples: Tesla opened a new Gigafactory in Berlin to serve the European market.
Netflix launched its streaming service in 130 new countries simultaneously.

name: CLOSED
description: An entity shutting down operations, branches, or product lines. This includes store closures, discontinuing services, or ceasing business.
examples: Google announced it would shut down its internal game development studios.
Macy's plans to close 125 department stores over the next three years.

name: REPORTED_FINANCIALS
description: An entity releasing its periodic financial results. This includes earnings reports, 10-Ks, 10-Qs, and revenue figures.
examples: Nvidia reported Q3 revenue of $18.1 billion, beating analyst estimates.
Tesla posted a decline in gross margins for the fiscal year 2023.

name: ISSUED_GUIDANCE
description: An entity providing forward-looking projections about its future performance. This includes raising or lowering revenue forecasts or EPS targets.
examples: Target warned of softer sales in the upcoming holiday quarter.
Microsoft raised its full-year revenue outlook citing strong cloud demand.

name: DECLARED_DIVIDEND
description: An entity announcing a payment to shareholders. This includes regular cash dividends, special dividends, or suspending dividends.
examples: Ford declared a supplemental dividend of 18 cents per share.
Disney announced it would reinstate its cash dividend after a three-year pause.

name: AUTHORIZED_BUYBACK
description: An entity announcing a plan to repurchase its own shares. This includes share repurchase programs and ASRs.
examples: Chevron announced a new $75 billion share buyback program.
Apple authorized an additional $90 billion for share repurchases.

name: ISSUED_DEBT
description: An entity raising capital by selling bonds or taking out loans. This includes notes offerings, credit facilities, and refinancing.
examples: Oracle sold $10 billion in bonds to fund its acquisition of Cerner.
Coinbase raised $1 billion through a convertible notes offering.

name: DEFAULTED
description: An entity failing to meet its debt obligations. This includes missing interest payments or principal repayments.
examples: Evergrande missed a crucial interest payment on its offshore bonds.
The country defaulted on its sovereign debt for the first time in a century.

name: FILED_BANKRUPTCY
description: An entity legally declaring inability to pay its debts. This includes Chapter 11 reorganization or Chapter 7 liquidation.
examples: FTX filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in Delaware.
WeWork officially filed for bankruptcy after years of struggles.

name: SETTLED_LEGAL_DISPUTE
description: An entity resolving a legal dispute, usually by paying a sum of money, without admitting liability. This includes class action settlements.
examples: Facebook agreed to pay $725 million to settle the Cambridge Analytica privacy lawsuit.
Juul settled thousands of lawsuits related to its marketing practices.

name: GRANTED_PATENT
description: An entity receiving official rights to an invention or intellectual property.
examples: IBM was granted a patent for a quantum computing processor.
Apple received a patent for a foldable iPhone display mechanism.

name: RECALLED_PRODUCT
description: An entity requesting the return of a product due to safety concerns or defects.
examples: Toyota recalled 1 million vehicles due to a potential airbag defect.
Peloton recalled its Tread+ treadmill following safety reports.

name: EXPERIENCED_DATA_BREACH
description: An entity suffering a security incident where sensitive data was accessed without authorization.
examples: T-Mobile revealed a data breach affecting 37 million customer accounts.
MGM Resorts suffered a cyberattack that disrupted its operations for days.

name: EXECUTIVE_RESIGNATION
description: A key executive or board member stepping down from their position.
examples: Jeff Bezos stepped down as CEO of Amazon to become Executive Chairman.
The CFO resigned unexpectedly citing personal reasons.

name: ANALYST_RATING_CHANGE
description: An external financial analyst changing their investment recommendation or price target for an entity.
examples: Goldman Sachs upgraded Netflix to 'Buy' from 'Neutral'.
Morgan Stanley downgraded the chipmaker citing inventory concerns.

name: RAISED_POLICY_RATE
description: A central bank increasing its benchmark interest rate to curb inflation or cool the economy.
examples: The Federal Reserve raised the federal funds rate by 25 basis points.
The European Central Bank hiked rates to combat soaring inflation.

name: LOWERED_POLICY_RATE
description: A central bank decreasing its benchmark interest rate to stimulate economic growth.
examples: The Bank of England cut interest rates to support the post-Brexit economy.
The PBOC lowered its loan prime rate to boost the property sector.

name: REPORTED_ECONOMIC_DATA
description: A government agency or organization releasing key economic indicators such as GDP, CPI, unemployment, or retail sales.
examples: The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported that the US economy added 336,000 jobs in September.
China reported a 4.5% GDP growth in the first quarter.

name: IMPOSED_SANCTIONS
description: A government or international body applying commercial and financial penalties against a targeted entity or country.
examples: The US imposed new sanctions on several Russian banks.
The EU announced trade restrictions on companies aiding the conflict.

name: ESTABLISHED_SUBSIDIARY
description: An entity creating a new separate legal entity to handle specific operations, often in a new region or sector.
examples: Alphabet established Waymo as a standalone subsidiary for self-driving technology.
Alibaba set up a new logistics subsidiary to handle international shipping.

name: INTEGRATED_SUBSIDIARY
description: An entity merging a subsidiary back into the parent company or consolidating operations.
examples: Microsoft integrated its Nuance acquisition into its healthcare division.
Disney consolidated its streaming services under a single media division.

name: SPUN_OFF
description: An entity creating an independent company from an existing division or subsidiary, distributing shares to existing shareholders.
examples: Johnson & Johnson spun off its consumer health business as Kenvue.
Daimler spun off its truck division into a separate listed company.

name: REPORTED_WAGE_PRESSURE_EASING
description: A report stating that the rate of wage growth is slowing down or that pressure to raise wages has diminished. A key inflation signal.
examples: Contacts noted that wage pressures were easing as the supply of labor improved.
Firms reported that wage growth had moderated back to pre-pandemic levels.

name: REPORTED_WAGE_PRESSURE_RISING
description: A report stating that businesses are facing increasing pressure to raise wages to attract or retain talent.
examples: Manufacturers reported continued upward pressure on wages due to skilled labor shortages.
Service firms raised starting wages significantly to compete for workers.

name: REPORTED_LABOR_MARKET_SOFTENING
description: A report indicating that hiring has slowed, turnover has decreased, or it has become easier to find workers.
examples: Hiring activity slowed across the district as firms became more cautious.
Contacts reported that it was easier to fill open positions than in previous months.

name: REPORTED_PRICING_POWER_EROSION
description: A report stating that businesses are unable to pass on higher costs to consumers due to pushback or competition.
examples: Retailers noted that customers were becoming more price-sensitive, limiting their ability to raise prices.
Firms reported that they had to absorb higher input costs as pricing power eroded.

name: REPORTED_CONSUMER_TRADING_DOWN
description: A report indicating that consumers are shifting purchases to cheaper alternatives or discount brands. A classic recessionary signal.
examples: Grocery stores reported that shoppers were trading down to private-label brands.
Discretionary spending shifted towards lower-cost entertainment options.

name: REPORTED_CREDIT_QUALITY_DETERIORATION
description: A report indicating a rise in delinquencies, defaults, or a decline in the creditworthiness of borrowers.
examples: Banks reported a slight uptick in delinquencies for subprime auto loans.
Credit card delinquency rates rose above pre-pandemic levels.

name: REPORTED_LENDING_STANDARDS_TIGHTENING
description: A report stating that banks are making it harder to get loans by increasing requirements or reducing limits.
examples: Lenders tightened standards for commercial real estate loans due to valuation concerns.
Banks reported stricter collateral requirements for business loans.

name: REPORTED_CRE_DISTRESS
description: A report highlighting specific stress in the Commercial Real Estate (CRE) sector, such as high vacancies or valuation drops.
examples: Office vacancy rates remained high, leading to distress in the downtown CRE market.
Contacts reported difficulty refinancing maturing office building loans.

name: REPORTED_INVENTORY_BUILDUP
description: A report stating that businesses have more inventory than desired, often leading to discounting.
examples: Retailers reported excess inventory in apparel and home goods.
Manufacturers noted an unintended buildup of finished goods as demand slowed.

name: REPORTED_CAPEX_DELAY
description: A report stating that businesses are postponing or cancelling planned capital expenditures due to uncertainty or high interest rates.
examples: Many firms reported pausing construction projects due to high financing costs.
Capital spending plans were scaled back amid economic uncertainty.

name: REPORTED_OUTLOOK_UNCERTAINTY
description: A report stating that business confidence has waned or that the future economic outlook has become more uncertain.
examples: Contacts expressed increased pessimism about the economic outlook for the next six months.
Uncertainty regarding the election caused firms to delay strategic decisions.

name: REPORTED_ECONOMIC_ACTIVITY
description: General statements about the overall speed or health of the economy (e.g., growth, stagnation, recession).
examples: Economic activity was little changed.
The pace of growth decelerated.

name: REPORTED_LABOR_CONDITIONS
description: Statements regarding employment levels, hiring difficulties, turnover, or labor supply.
examples: Hiring was flat.
Firms reported difficulty finding skilled workers.

name: REPORTED_WAGE_TRENDS
description: Specific reporting on salary changes, wage pressures, or compensation costs. (Distinct from general labor conditions).
examples: Wage growth moderated.
Starting salaries rose 10%.

name: REPORTED_PRICE_PRESSURES
description: Statements regarding inflation, input costs, or selling prices.
examples: Input costs rose due to tariffs.
Selling prices held steady.

name: REPORTED_CONSUMER_SPENDING
description: Trends in retail, tourism, hospitality, and general consumer demand.
examples: Retailers noted softer demand for discretionary items.
Tourism activity exceeded expectations.

name: REPORTED_CREDIT_CONDITIONS
description: Banking sector reports on loan volume, credit quality, delinquency, or lending standards.
examples: Loan demand fell due to high rates.
Credit quality remained healthy.

name: REPORTED_REAL_ESTATE
description: Specifics on commercial or residential real estate markets, construction, and leasing.
examples: Commercial office vacancy rates remained high.
Home sales were flat.

name: CAUSED
description: One event, action, or entity directly causing another event, state, or outcome. A fundamental cause-and-effect relationship.
examples: The software update caused the system to crash.
High winds caused power outages across the region.
The CEO's comments caused the stock price to drop.

name: EFFECTED_BY
description: An event, state, or outcome that is the direct result of another event, action, or entity. The passive form of CAUSED.
examples: The system crash was effected by the software update.
Power outages were effected by high winds.
The drop in stock price was effected by the CEO's comments.

name: CONTRIBUTED_TO
description: An event or factor that played a part in bringing about a result, but was not the sole cause.
examples: Rising interest rates contributed to the slowdown in housing sales.
Supply chain disruptions contributed to the lower quarterly revenue.
Strong marketing contributed to the product's success.

name: PREVENTED
description: An action or event that stopped another event or outcome from happening.
examples: The safety mechanism prevented a catastrophic failure.
Early intervention prevented the spread of the virus.
Regulatory hurdles prevented the merger from completing.

name: HEADQUARTERED_IN
description: An organization having its main office or headquarters located in a specific place (city, state, country).
examples: Alphabet Inc. is headquartered in Mountain View, California.
The company's global headquarters are located in New York City.
The bank's corporate headquarters is in Charlotte, North Carolina.

name: HAS_TICKER
description: An organization having a specific stock ticker symbol used for trading on exchanges.
examples: Alphabet trades under the ticker symbols GOOGL and GOOG.
The company's stock is listed as AAPL on the NASDAQ.
Tesla's ticker symbol is TSLA.

name: TRADES_ON
description: An organization's stock being listed and traded on a specific stock exchange.
examples: Alphabet trades on the NASDAQ stock exchange.
The company is listed on the New York Stock Exchange.
The firm went public on the London Stock Exchange.

name: HAS_MOTTO
description: An organization adopting or using a specific slogan, motto, or tagline.
examples: Google's informal motto was 'Don't be evil'.
Alphabet's corporate code of conduct includes 'Do the right thing'.
Nike's famous slogan is 'Just Do It'.

name: FOUNDED_IN
description: An organization being established or incorporated in a specific year or time period.
examples: Google was founded in 1998.
Alphabet Inc. was created in 2015 as a restructuring of Google.
The company was established in the early 2000s.

name: OPERATES_IN
description: An organization conducting business or having operations in a specific geographic region, country, or market.
examples: Google operates in over 100 countries worldwide.
The company has significant operations in Asia Pacific.
Alphabet operates across North America, Europe, and emerging markets.

name: HAS_WEBSITE
description: An organization's official website or web domain.
examples: Google's website is google.com.
The company's official website is alphabet.com.
Investors can find information at investor.google.com.

name: LED_BY
description: An organization being managed or led by a specific person in a leadership role (CEO, CFO, President, Chairman, etc.).
examples: Alphabet is led by CEO Sundar Pichai.
The company is headed by its founder and executive chairman.
Ruth Porat serves as President and Chief Investment Officer of Alphabet.

name: OFFERS_PRODUCT
description: An organization providing or selling a specific product to customers.
examples: Google offers the Chrome web browser.
Alphabet offers Google Cloud Platform for enterprise customers.
The company offers a range of Pixel smartphones.

name: PROVIDES_SERVICE
description: An organization delivering a specific service to users or customers.
examples: Google provides search engine services.
YouTube provides video streaming and hosting services.
Google Cloud provides cloud computing and storage services.

name: REVEALED
description: A person or organization publicly disclosing or revealing previously unknown information, a decision, an inspiration, or internal details.
examples: The whistleblower revealed the accounting fraud to regulators.
Internal memos revealed tensions between the board and management.
The documentary revealed how the company evaded taxes for years.

name: DISCLOSED
description: A person or organization formally disclosing information, often in official or regulatory contexts.
examples: JPMorgan disclosed a $2 billion trading loss in its London office.
The proxy statement disclosed executive compensation details.
Tesla disclosed ongoing SEC investigations in its 10-K filing.

name: ANNOUNCED
description: A person or organization making a formal public announcement about a decision, event, or plan.
examples: Microsoft announced the acquisition of Activision Blizzard.
The Federal Reserve announced quantitative tightening.
Boeing announced delays to the 777X program.

name: INSPIRED_BY
description: An organization's structure, product, or strategy being inspired or influenced by another entity, person, or model.
examples: SpaceX's vertical integration was inspired by Ford's River Rouge plant.
The iPhone design was inspired by Braun's minimalist aesthetics.
Toyota's production system inspired lean manufacturing worldwide.

name: MODELED_AFTER
description: An organization explicitly modeling its structure, operations, or approach after another entity.
examples: Softbank's Vision Fund was modeled after sovereign wealth funds.
The European Union's antitrust approach was modeled after US regulations.
Costco's membership model was modeled after Price Club.

name: ENCOURAGED
description: A person encouraging or urging another person or organization to take a specific action or make a decision.
examples: Carl Icahn encouraged Apple to increase its stock buyback program.
The activist investor encouraged the board to consider a sale.
Mentors at Y Combinator encouraged the founders to pivot.

name: ADVISED
description: A person or organization providing advice or counsel to another entity on a decision or strategy.
examples: Morgan Stanley advised Twitter on its sale to Elon Musk.
McKinsey advised the automaker on its EV transition strategy.
The former Treasury Secretary advised the startup on regulatory matters.

name: RECOMMENDED
description: A person or organization making a formal recommendation about an action, investment, or decision.
examples: The proxy advisory firm recommended voting against the merger.
Credit Suisse recommended overweight on semiconductor stocks.
The compensation committee recommended a 20% raise for the CEO.
